entry.title: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to change field status of Purchase Requisition
entry.content:
Problem Background:

We received a customer request: when creating a purchase requisition, they want the Valuation Price field to be optional, but in the current system this field is mandatory.

Solution:

Attempt to meet the requirement through custom logic using a BAdI.

Analysis Steps:

1. After searching in SAP for Me, we found a KBA 3322867 - Valuation Price field is mandatory in Create Purchase Requisitions app - SAP for Me which provides a solution to this problem. So we can try to use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PR_ FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE to solve this problem.

2. We enter APP Custom Logic to create an implementation. The description of this BAdI is "Change of Field Control for Purchase Requisitions". In the documentation, we can get more information including supported fields. "PURCHASEREQUISITIONPRICE - Valuation Price" is included, that means our requirement can be fulfilled by this BAdI.

3. With this BAdI, we can set four status for supported fields of Purchase Requisition: Hidden, Read-only, Mandatory, Optional.

  • '-': To hide the field
  • '*': To make the field read-only
  • '+': To make the field mandatory
  • '.': To make the field optional

4. The sample code of this BAdI is quite readable and easy. Based on this problem, implement the BAdI. The specific code is as follows.

FIELD-SYMBOLS <fs> TYPE mmpur_s_pr_fldsel.

READ TABLE fieldselection_table ASSIGNING <fs> WITH KEY field = 'PURCHASEREQUISITIONPRICE'.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
    <fs>-fieldstatus = '.'.
ENDIF.

5. After testing, the BAdI works prefect. This BAdI not only supports GUI APP - Create Purchase Requisition - Advanced, but also supports Fiori APP - Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional.

Conclusion:

By reading this article and several previous blogs on similar scenarios, I hope you now understand how to use custom logic to apply certain restrictions when creating preliminary invoices for purchase orders.
You can find more information about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement-related issues at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

You can also read more blogs about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

If you have any suggestions or thoughts about this article, please feel free to share them in the comments section. I look forward to communicating with you. You are also welcome to follow my personal account, and I look forward to seeing you in the next blog post!

entry.title: SAP RPT‑1: Why is it Essential for Predicting Business Outcomes in Today’s and Future Generative AI?
entry.content:
Ever since the introduction of ChatGPT in November 2022, Generative AI has reshaped the AI industry. Companies like Amazon, Google, Microsoft, and of course SAP have accelerated innovation, recognizing the enormous value Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) bring to enterprise operations. 

General‑purpose LLMs excel at understanding language, reasoning over text, and identifying patterns in unstructured information. They are creative, adaptive, and capable of leveraging data from files, documents, and multimedia across diverse data systems.

The Motive

However, when it comes to actually predicting business outcomes, LLMs fall short. Why?
Because they are not designed for high‑precision, multi‑step reasoning over large, enterprise‑grade tabular datasets.

And this is where the majority of business data resides: structured tables, such as GL accounts, invoices, inventory, sales records, financial transactions, and countless others. Not in free‑form text.

Everyone wants to be able to predict business outcomes like:

  • What is the probability of converting a sale?
  • Which customers are likely to pay late?
  • Who is at risk of churn?
  • ...
Historically, answering these questions required traditional machine learning like classification models, linear regression, etc. (a.k.a Traditional AI or Narrow AI). The problem with this is that classical ML requires to train a model per task, which easily can lead to hundreds of separate models hard to maintain in the long run, making it very cumbersome, expensive and extremely difficult to scale.
 
 
The Solution: SAP RPT-1
 
To solve this, SAP introduced in TechEd 2025 the first foundation model specifically designed for structured enterprise data: Relational Pre‑Trained Transformer 1 (RPT‑1).  The model is trained natively on tabular business datasets and is engineered to understand rows, columns, joins and business semantics out of the box. As the name suggests, RPT‑1 is:
  • Relational: optimized for structured relational business data
  • Pre‑trained: powered by tens of thousands of GPU hours (no more endless classical ML training cycles)
  • Transformer‑based: performs logical, not linguistic, transformations (e.g., filtering, joining, aggregating, and multi‑step reasoning)

Instead of hundreds of ML models, you now can use one single foundation model for many predictive tasks.

One of the most disruptive features of RPT‑1 is its in‑context learning capability. Instead of training or fine‑tuning multiple modes, you simple provide historical rows of data and request predictions for new rows. Prediction cases like:

  • Customer churn prediction
  • Late delivery prediction
  • Late payment prediction
  • Sales conversion prediction
  • And many more

RPT‑1 Performance Benchmark

RPT-1 outperforms both LLM and classical ML for tabular data and high value agentic cases. Here are some stats so far:

  • 50x faster than LLMs
  • Up to 2x Prediction Quality vs Narrow AI/ML Models
  • Up to 3.5x Prediction Quality vs LLMs
  • 100,000x fewer GPU FLOPs
  • 50,000x Less Energy consumption vs LLMs*

*comparable tasks on a NVIDIA H100, as a benchmark. Sources (TechEd, Blog) .

Why are these stats so important? On top of the benefits you can already imagine like time and resource savings; according to Gartner 40% of agentic-AI projects are likely to be canceled by end of 2027, mainly because of high cost, complexity, or unclear business value (source). RPT‑1 directly addresses these challenges.

 

Sales Conversion Prediction Example Use Case

During SAP TechEd, a compelling demo showcased how RPT‑1 integrates with SAP’s Agentic AI.

Imagine a sales team wanting to prioritize leads based on their likelihood to convert. Instead of manually training an ML model, a data analyst can use Joule to generate SQL code leveraging RPT‑1’s PREDICT function.

Steps include:

  1. Join sales inquiries, historical performance, customer attributes, and other relevant data into a Data Product in SAP Business Data Cloud.
  2. Expose the Data Product to SAP HANA Cloud via zero‑copy.
  3. Use RPT‑1 to instantly generate a new prediction column "sales_conversion_probability"; without training or tuning.

The model derives patterns directly from the historical data and produces high‑quality prediction scores.

You can watch the full demo here (jump to minute 35:23).

 

Available RPT‑1 Versions

SAP RPT‑1 has been generally available since Q4 2025. You can choose from:

  • SAP RPT‑1 Small: optimized for speed and efficiency
  • SAP RPT‑1 Large: optimized for highest accuracy by using more capacity
  • SAP RPT‑1 OSS (Open Source): available on HuggingFace and Github for exploration and learning

Try it yourself!

Don’t have access to a BTP account yet? here is an entry point:

  • Sign up for a 30-day SAP Generative AI Hub trial
  • Follow this step-by-step guide to get started by @sherene_tan 

 

Conclusion

SAP RPT‑1 represents a major shift in how enterprises will deliver predictive insights in the GenAI era. While LLMs excel at language understanding, they are not built for structured, relational business data. RPT‑1 closes this gap and eliminates the complexity of traditional machine learning, drastically reducing cost and compute.

With SAP RPT-1's foundation model purpose‑built for enterprise-grade tabular data, the objective is to enable organizations to operationalize predictive insights faster, more efficiently, and more accurately than ever before.

entry.title: Exchange Rate Conversion in I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'm working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and using the I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2 CDS view for project forecasting reporting. Currently, the cube displays amounts in USD, but I need to convert them to our company currency (KRW) for reporting purposes.

I have the following questions:

1. CDS View for Currency Conversion:

  • Is there a standard CDS view that extends I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2 with currency conversion to company currency (KRW)?

  • If not, what is the recommended approach to implement currency conversion in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition? Should I create a custom CDS view using the CURRENCY_CONVERSION function?

2. Exchange Rate Type and Timing:

I understand that exchange rate type P (Planning Rate) is used for project planning. However, I need clarification on the following:

  • Plan values: Are they converted using the exchange rate P valid at the time of plan document creation (based on posting date or document date)?

  • Actual values: Are they converted using the exchange rate at the actual posting date of each transaction?

  • ETC (Estimate to Complete): Which exchange rate date is used - current forecast period or a specific date?

  • EAC (Estimate at Completion): Does it follow the same logic as Plan, or is there a different timing rule?

3. Documentation:

Is there any official SAP documentation or Note that describes the exchange rate timing rules for Plan/Actual/ETC/EAC in PS/EPPM module for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

Background:

  • System: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • Module: EPPM (PS)

  • CDS View: I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2

  • Source Currency: USD

  • Target Currency: KRW

  • Exchange Rate Type: P

Any guidance or reference to official documentation would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance!

Best regards,

entry.title: Management of Mold Manufacturing
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

Our factory carries out mold manufacturing operations. For certain stages of the molds produced, subcontracting services are obtained from external companies. During the mold manufacturing process, various raw materials are combined and processed, resulting in the final product, the mold.

When we attempt to manage this process as an ongoing investment, we have identified that we are unable to track the inventory of our materials that are located at the subcontractor’s site. On the other hand, when we try to manage the process using a subcontracting routing, this approach does not yield healthy results for us due to the mold manufacturing lead time exceeding one month and the WIP process being closed.

We do not prefer to create separate material master records for each component, as we believe that generating an excessive number of material codes would unnecessarily complicate the system. Once the mold manufacturing is completed and the mold is received into inventory, it will be managed as a fixed asset.

Within this framework, we would highly appreciate your valuable opinions and recommendations on how this process can be correctly and traceably designed in SAP.
In your opinion, what would be the healthiest way to manage this process?

Kind regards,

entry.title: Access SAP S/4HANA Transaction Codes in SAP BTP Build Work Zone
entry.content:
Hello Everybody,

 

Writing this blog to explain how we can access the SAP Transaction Codes of S/4HANA On Premise (SAP Rise) from SAP BTP Build Work Zone. SAP S/4HANA Rise system is a private cloud example, we can use public cloud also.

Here we are using SAP BTP Build Work Zone, Standard Edition. You can also use SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition also.

Prerequisites: Below are the prerequisites before we start:

-> Within the global account, you should subscribed to SAP Build Work Zone, standard edtion Service and Configured the Cloud Identity Service. The Work Zone will use Identity Authentication Service (IAS) to authenticate the Business Users.

-> In the Cloud Connector, configure the backend s/4hana system with https port for secure tunneled access and exchange the certifiate for Principal Propagation (The user of PP should be same in IAS and S4)

-> Destination should be there in the Sub account and choose the Principal Propagation as authentication.

 

Configuration:  There are 2 ways to configure the application, Page, spaces etc. in the build work zone:

1. Content Federation from S/4HANA system: In this we need to create the artifacts (Space, Pages, app etc.) in the S4 system and federate the content by making the content channel.

2. Local Artifcats in the Work Zone: Create Local Apps, Pages, spaces, groups etc. as required in the build work zone, standard edition.

 

We will be using the 2nd option as we are going to create local content in the work zone. Below are the configuration steps:

Step 1: Create App in the work zone

Access the Build Work Zone from the Sub account and got to Content Manager

Create a local app in the work zone, choose System (Destination) and form App UI Technology choose the SAP GUI for HTML

in this case, I have choosen the below transaction code, here we can put any transaction code as required

Step 2: Create page and assign app to page

Create a page and assign the appto page as below:

 

Step 3: Create Space and assign page to Space

 

Step 4: Create Role and assign app, space to role

 

Step 5:  Assign role to the site so it will be visible in site

Step 6: Assign role to user in Sub Account

Please note, Role created in the Work Zone will be shown as Role Collection in the Sub Account. So go to sub account and choose Role Collection and assign user to it.

 

Result: After Configuration all the above steps, when user will access the Work Zone then they can able to access the SAP S/4HANA transaction code as below:

 

I Hope this blog will help people to configure the SAP Transaction Code in Build Work Zone quickly without any issue.

 

Regards,

Rohit Gera

entry.title: Best Practice for Adjusting Project Progress Percentage in Review Customer Project
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'm working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition(fiori), and I need clarification on the standard process for adjusting project progress percentage when it doesn't match external tracking systems.

Current Situation:

  • External stakeholders track project progress separately, and their progress % often differs from SAP's calculated PoC

  • I need to increase or decrease progress percentage during the project lifecycle to align with external reporting

My Current Process:

  • During the project: I've been adjusting Plan values (increasing or decreasing planned costs) app to manipulate the progress percentage

  • At project end: I set ETC to 0 and run event-based revenue recognition to force 100% completion

  • I have NOT been setting forecast months regularly throughout the project

My Questions:

  1. Is adjusting Plan values the correct approach for mid-project progress reconciliation, or should I be using ETC adjustments instead?

  2. What is the SAP-recommended standard practice for ongoing progress alignment when external progress differs from system-calculated PoC?

  3. Should I be using forecast month settings systematically throughout the project lifecycle rather than only at project closure?

  4. What are the risks or downstream impacts of frequently modifying Plan values vs. ETC values?

  5. Are there official SAP guidelines or best practice documents for PoC adjustments in the Review Customer Project app?

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
Thanks for taking up this difficult topic.

I see some large problems with the shift left approach so I fully agree that we will see a hybrid going forward.

The problems I see are

a) Back-end designers and developers don't understand what it data it takes to do analysis or even make AI on data

b) Back-end designers and developers are under pressure to deliver features and functionality not down-stream analytical useability

c) Not all can be standard and standards are not flexible.

ad a) The BW business content for ewm was a perfect example of back-end developers trying to deliver what they imagined was needed. The problem was that they did not understand the BW model leaving parts of the content pretty useless.

ad b) Most of us are measured on delivering results as fast as possible and that is not taking into account how much time is used down-stream by other teams.

ad c) In e.g. sales we we partner functions, some are standard like sold-to and ship-to but we have 3 custom partner functions that we can't run the business without. This will never come out of the box. Another example is classification data for materials. Using data products makes it worse as they are very inflexible of nature.

With kind regards

Kristian Appel

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP - IS - ( IA | CPI ) - The Commander's Blueprint: Rebuilding B2B EDI Governance with SAP
entry.content:
A long blog that could cover multiply topics. 

There is a number of decisions to take as a part of understanding your future EDI setup. 

Using the Standard TPM content is a good way to avoid the hey we just can just build it. It is a little as painful as building something in SAP PI where you where forced to use the framework. But here it makes a lot of sense to ensure you can build something that scales. 

Having a solid framework for governance around the TPM setup and roles is crucial. That include change history, transport and testing to understand what is going on. Here Figaf tool can help. 

There is a lot of strange rules inside your B2B Mappings because someone interpreted the business logic and someone else created the rules for it. Ideally we get out of this mess and get more clearly defined messages. But that would require a huge effort to find all the documents created. And MIG / MAG + a good sharepoint place to add all the documents too would make a huge difference.

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
Hello @Phil_from_Madrid 

to be honest... I read your blog twice, but still asking myself: "Where is the beef?"

I still don't understand your intention or your goal of this Blog?!

I've been a BW consultant for 20 years now, and I can fully agree with your BW part: Extractors, and especially BI Content have been the "data products" of today, for over 25 years, without any specific term. And I think even today, that content contained more than the current Data Products in SAP Datasphere... not only because there is none in SD or MM LoB, but also because there have been features and functionalities already 20 years ago, for which we have to fight via the influence portal, to get them again.

One example... and I'm sure, this will be one of the last things, around 2029 to be delivered, if at all: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/365526  

And one last thought... what bothers me from the beginning of the introduction of the term "data product" ... for me, a product is something that is basically finished, like goods you buy in a shop: Pants, Jacket, Refrigerator, TV, a car etc. it is like you bought it and does not change, unless you customize it by yourself.

For e.g. a final Forecast, Plan or Budget version, the term "data product" applies... it does not change anymore (usually). But for master data or actuals data, it changes every hour, every day... it is a temporary product only. Especially if a process changes, the same data exists as "old and new" data product, if e.g. more document types are contained in one year than the other (just an example).

I know, I will not be able to change this "logic", but I think it is still worth thinking about it. 😉

BR, Martin

entry.title: Re: Wrong value in "current phase" SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Hello Thomas,

The value in the current phase of the user story is taken from the current phase of the project.
While creating a user story, you can set the phase for it from the drop down of timebox.
We have a KBA 3117475 about how to assign user stories to sprints, but you can review it to get an idea about how to assign user stories to phases.

Best regards,
Ellie

entry.title: Re: Not Found - GET http://nginx-redirector.repo-cache.sv...
entry.content:
Face the same issue here when npm install. Fixed it by following:

1. Remove package-lock.json

2. Execute command `npm set registry=https://registry.npmjs.org/`

3. `npm install`

In my case, package-lock.json was created in BAS. And when I tried to clone the repo and do npm install in my local machine, it occurs

npm error network request to http://nginx-redirector.repo-cache.svc.cluster.local/repository/appstudio-npm-group/@sap/ux-ui5-tooling/-/ux-ui5-tooling-1.6.7.tgz failed, reason: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND nginx-redirector.repo-cache.svc.cluster.local

I guess because the proxy got stored in package-lock.json, so remove package-lock.json shall be enough to solve the issue.

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content: @FernandoPerezMerino : Hi Fernando, of course I remember, ages ago, but good times. Thanks for taking the time to read and comment. The BDC object store is imho and in the theory the Silver layer, as it is positioned as the data distributing point, see Delta sharing. SAP calls the object that arrive there the "data products". Gold can combine these data sets and add "informational value" to these assests by deriving or combining them. That's what you call "secondary data products". These may be more specific for a given use case. SAP is offering their data products as is without the possiblity to intervene beforehand (apart of extensions). So they took the burden to make them good quality products that should be shared with other platforms further downstream. Kind regards, Philipp

entry.title: Re: IH01 – Plant Field Is Prefilled by Default
entry.content:
Many fields are pre-filled using a parameter known as the SPA/GPA parameter. You can access this parameter by pressing F1 on the field to display technical information, where the parameter ID is listed as 'WRK' in your case?

The initial value for these fields is derived from the parameter value in transaction SU3. This value is then read and updated by various transactions using the parameter ID 'WRK,' which means the last used plant is set as the default.

Occasionally, the dynpro does not carry the parameter ID value, but the PBO/PAI modules use GET/SET PARAMETER ID statements to handle it.

Tips:

  • Transaction IH01 allows the creation of a user default variant. You can create one with the name 'U' + user_id, which might enable you to force the value of p_werk.
  • Alternatively, you can utilize existing BAdIs (Business Add-Ins) or implicit enhancement points to clear the parameter ID 'WRK.' For example, you can use BADI_EAM_STRUCTURE_LIST and test for a BAdI that executes early in the transaction.

entry.title: Re: Fixed asset: Asset Class without Useful Life
entry.content:
Create a Custom Depreciation Key for assets that should not undergo depreciation.

  • Depreciation Method: Set it to 'None' with a 0% rate.
  • Transaction Code AW01: Use this to define the new depreciation key.
  • Transaction Code OAWS: Use this to assign the depreciation key to the relevant asset classes

NB: Check if a key named '0000' already exists, as it might be suitable (used for AUC)

Assign this depreciation key to your asset. Note that the useful life will only be utilized in certain reporting scenarios.

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
@appel_solar_dk : Thanks for sharing your thoughts. The article can be thought of like a thought experiment, trying to weight the hurdles and benefits of "consequently shifting left". It might be incomplete and not respect all specific cases. And yes, you are right with all points. These are considerable aspects, also from an organizational, staffing and cultural perspective when "shift left" the responsibility and not only the logic. So, the shift left approach suddenly grows in impact, if done consequently. Showing this was one of the intentions. Apply the thought for your points consequently to your scenarios and I would expect that you get a good first checklist if and under which circumstances shift left (which has its benefits for me, no doubt) is reasonable.

About c: Formally, the 3 different roles you mention are reference characteristics of 0CUSTOMER ( for the BW people). If you would have needed additional attributes in the past, you would need a new info object (I call them derived) with more data, independently from where you read the data. But this might be a customer-specific extension. If the case is so specific in the "new world" that it can not be derived from the central customer master data, you would need in the "new world" a custom data product generator, so you would pick up the definition and the responsibility , and that would be against "shift left", unless you are organizationally belonging to the backend. 

Like with most discussions around data modeling, there is no black and white, it's a thought model to handle complexity of a (source) data model. Look at LSA(++). There were plenty of discussions and interpreations back then. I saw total overkills in staging in quite some systems.

But over time, certain common ground was established in many systems. Same happens in the medallion architecture, and same will happen sooner or later here, I guess, especially if SAP succeeds with their idea.

Kind regards, Philipp

entry.title: Re: Using Migration Assessment to Plan Your SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migra
entry.content:
Hi Vinay,

thanks for sharing your perspective and for linking your blog. This is an important discussion, and I appreciate you raising it.

Just to clarify our positioning: we consistently highlight that the Migration Assessment provides an estimation of the technical migration effort only, based on static analysis of PI/PO artifacts. It explicitly does not include effort for testing, business validation, cutover and go-live activities, or sender and receiver system adaptations.

These aspects are highly customer dependent, and so far we have not found a reliable way to derive them automatically via a tool, as they depend on the customer’s chosen frameworks, governance model, and quality requirements. That said, we are always open to feedback if you see an approach on how such aspects could be meaningfully included.

This is why we always recommend a follow-up deep-dive workshop, typically together with SAP or our partners, to validate assumptions and create a realistic end-to-end migration plan. We have strong SAP teams and partners supporting customers in exactly this phase.

Regarding the example you mentioned (e.g. ~700 days for 1000+ interfaces), I would be very interested to better understand the drivers behind such an estimation. From our experience over the last year, we have seen several projects where customers with large landscapes (100+ interfaces) achieved a significantly lower average effort per interface, provided the migration was well prepared and executed in a structured way.

Of course, this is not something we would generalize blindly — preparation, planning, interface patterns, and governance make a big difference. Key factors we typically see influencing migration efficiency are early clustering of interfaces, identifying synergies, starting with simpler interfaces, and at the same time addressing more complex ones in parallel.

It would be great to learn more about the specific constraints or patterns you see driving higher effort in such scenarios. Feedback like this helps us further sharpen how we position the assessment and guide both customers and partners.

Best regards,
Richard

entry.title: Re: Is output print preview button available in Manage Sa...
entry.content:
No, the app does not provide a Print Preview button by default. That's because Fiori apps of type "Manage" do not include output functions directly.

To answer your second question: You can't directly add a Print Preview button as you can not enhance the app itself. The app is SAP-delivered and no key-user extensible at header-action level is provided - to my knowledge.  But what you can do is, you can add a custom tile linking to a custom Print Preview app. In other words, you can build a custom as follows:

  • A side‑by‑side CAP/RAP app
  • That calls Output Management APIs
  • Embedded in the Fiori Launchpad as a tile or navigation link

    I hope that it helped.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM C_STC Certification Reimagined: From Multiple Choice to AI Roleplay
entry.content:
We’re excited to announce that the SAP Cloud ALM C_STC certification has moved to SAP’s reimagined certification experience on learning.sap.com. The assessment is now scenario-based AI roleplay, designed to reflect real stakeholder conversations and decision making. To support this change, we are introducing a refreshed Learning Journey that consists of both updated courses and newly created courses—so you can prepare with confidence.

 

Announcement

SAP Cloud ALM C_STC (SAP Certified Associate – Solution Transformation Consultant with SAP Cloud ALM) is now available on the new SAP Certification platform and aligned with SAP’s reimagined certification approach.

C_STC is assessed through scenario-based interaction (AI roleplay), intended to mirror real project stakeholder conversations and validate how you apply knowledge in context.

For already-certified professionals: please follow the official guidance on maintaining certification (e.g., take the delta course and stay-certified assessments) as applicable.

 

What Changed (and Why It Matters)

The reimagined model shifts the focus from memorization to outcomes: practical, performance-based assessment, open-book by design, and timeboxed challenges that resemble real project work. The goal is to prove what you can do—how you structure a response, use available resources, and turn understanding into an actionable recommendation.

 

Refreshed Learning Journey: Updated + New Courses for STCs

To match the new certification experience, we strengthened the learning path for Solution Transformation Consultants (STCs). The refreshed Learning Journey brings together updated courses and newly created courses into a clearer end-to-end storyline—from the integrated toolchain and SAP Cloud ALM fundamentals, through implementation and operations, and into how SAP Cloud ALM supports RISE with SAP and Clean Core topics.

Key Courses in the Learning Journey: Transforming for Success with SAP Cloud ALM 

BTM004 (NEW) – Navigating RISE with SAP Transformations Leveraging the Integrated Toolchain: A short, sprint-based case study that shows how SAP LeanIX, SAP Signavio, and SAP Cloud ALM work together as an integrated toolchain to enable data-driven, end-to-end transformation delivery—and how to reuse the provided assets in customer conversations.

CALM01(Updated) – Introducing SAP Cloud ALM: Your starting point for a unified view of SAP Cloud ALM across implementation and operations. It helps you evaluate Cloud ALM’s value (cost reduction, faster time-to-market, operational efficiency) and includes a dedicated Transition unit to support your move to SAP Cloud ALM.

CALM05 (NEW) – Onboarding, Setting Up, and Administering SAP Cloud ALM: A practical onboarding and setup guide that takes you from requesting SAP Cloud ALM to user onboarding and role assignments, and then into key integration and configuration options—so you can get to meaningful hands-on work faster.

CALM20 (Updated) – Implementing with SAP Cloud ALM: A deep dive into using SAP Cloud ALM for agile implementation projects, aligned with SAP Activate. It covers project/team setup, process definition, requirements, testing, analytics, and guidance to plan your transition regarding Implementation features from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM.

CALM61 (NEW) – Harnessing SAP Cloud ALM for Effective Transformation Execution with RISE: Learn how SAP Cloud ALM serves as the digital backbone for RISE with SAP, and how it supports Clean Core across five dimensions (processes, data, integration, extensions, operations). It also introduces the purpose and access of the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard.

We’ll continue to enhance this Learning Journey with ongoing updates—stay tuned for what’s next.

 

How to Prepare for Scenario-Based AI Roleplay

Prepare the way you work: practice explaining your approach, rationale, and trade-offs in clear, structured language. Make sure you can connect SAP Cloud ALM capabilities to the transformation storyline. That combination—content mastery plus communication—best matches what a scenario-based assessment is intended to validate.

 

Quick Links

  • Reimagining certification (SAP Learning): https://learning.sap.com/get-certified/reimagining-certification 
  • C_STC certification page: https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-associate-solution-transformation-consultant-with-sap-cloud-alm 
  • Learning Journey: Transforming for Success with SAP Cloud ALM: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/transforming-for-success-with-sap-cloud-alm 
  • SAP Cloud ALM learning portal: https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/learning.html

entry.title: Use BTP Malware Service with VSCAN (VSI) - Detect hidden code in metadata of image file
entry.content:
Hi,

I have a requirement where we need to scan files uploaded via a Fiori application for malware (in our case attachments for a leave request). After some research I came across this amazing github project ( https://github.com/gregorwolf/sap-malware-scanning-vsi ) that explains how you can use the BTP malware service via the VSI BAdI to do your virus/malware scanning. 

We initiated the BTP Malware instance, created the SM59 config, created all the classes and interfaces as per the github project, implemented the BADI and created the basic VSI configuration. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Now that all seems to be working correctly. When I use VSCANTEST with the standard Eicar test virus, it correctly detects the virus.

 However when I try something more complex like hiding executable PHP code within the metadata of an image file, it does not detect this as malware :(. I tried searching through all available documentation, and it seems as if the VSI profile configuration options where you specify MIME types for active content is only if you configure a malware service via VSI and not when you use the BADI?

Has anyone tried this before where you use the VSI BADI to call a malware scanning service (Like the BTP one) and scan for things like PHP code in metadata? How I do that?

Kind Regards

Deon

entry.title: Re: Why do I need to process Service Confirmation?
entry.content:
Dear @ISoma,

In Public Cloud (Service Management), Service Entry Sheet (SES) and Service Confirmation serve two different purposes, even when you are procuring an external service item in a service order

Why SES does not complete the service order:

  • SES = procurement acceptance, it confirms that the supplier delivered the external service against the PO and it is the basis for supplier invoicing and MM/FI postings
  • Service Confirmation = service execution reporting, it confirms that the service activity in the service order was actually executed in the service process and it is what drives the service-order execution status and follow-on steps such as final completion and where relevant billing readiness. SAP describes confirmations as the place to report actuals like duration/material/expenses for service execution

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/adbae5bcd5994f159bf2847a11397b61/f51f9127ec904db69be5bfc40cfcaeb4.html

So, after SES approval, the system still considers the service order item as not yet execution-confirmed from a Service perspective.

What the Confirmation tab is doing and why SAP requires it:

In the standard process, once an activity is completed, a follow-up service confirmation is created and set to Completed and if it is the last one, final Confirmation must be set
That final confirmation is the systems control point to:

  • prove completion of the service work,
  • freeze execution so no further actuals/consumption are expected for that item,
  • drive the service order lifecycle status to Completed because completion is defined as execution is fully confirmed not merely procurement is accepted

More details below:

https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-service-management/creating-service-orders-and-service-confirmations_d9a942ce-e887-4c86-9c5b-b955255b15ba

Can you set the Service Order to Completed without service confirmation?

In standard Public Cloud NO, not if the item categories/order type are designed to be confirmation-relevant. The Completed lifecycle status is effectively system-controlled based on execution completion logic completion/final confirmation, not just a manual status toggle. If your business requirement is close the order after SES, SAP expects you to still create at least one final service confirmation even if it contains no time/expenses because that is the step that declares execution is finished

Practical options to minimize or avoid manual effort:

Option A: Recommended standard approach

After SES is approved:

  1. Go to Confirmations tab
  2. Create/select the confirmation for the relevant items
  3. Set Status = Completed
  4. Tick Final Confirmation
  5. Save

This is usually a lightweight step, but it is what allows the order to reach Completed

Option B: Automate confirmation creation/completion

If the issue is operational overhead, the typical approach is to automate the creation + completion of the service confirmation triggered by SES approval for example using SAP Build Process Automation or an integration flow. Conceptually this keeps SAP control logic intact but removes manual work

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Universal Revenue Recognition (URR) Configuration Walkthrough – Release 2602
entry.content:
Introduction

This guide walks you through the configuration of Universal Revenue Recognition (URR). URR combines Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) and Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR) and therefore consists of two main parts: configuration in EBRR and configuration in CBRR. Because URR leverages the strengths of both approaches, the EBRR and CBRR settings apply to different areas.

 

Configuration in EBRR relates to:

  – Integration with business processes

  – Account determination

  – Posting rules

Configuration in CBRR relates to:

  – Deriving attributes for CBRR-related  objects

  – Defining standalone selling price (SSP) for price allocation when an SSP cannot be defined in the order system

General steps

Below are the configuration steps at a glance:

Pricing configuration in Sales

  1. Define a condition type for SSP
  2.  Add the SSP condition type to the pricing procedure
  3.  Maintain SSP condition records for the product

Configuration in EBRR:

  1.  Maintain Source Mapping (optional)
  2.  Maintain Accounts for Posting (optional)
  3.  Define Billable Determination Method (required)
  4.  Enable 'Use Revenue Contracts' via the Bundling Scenario

Configuration in CBRR (Revenue and Cost Accounting)

  1.   Maintain contract and POB attributes
  2.   Define Standalone Selling Price (optional — only if SSP is not defined in Sales)

This guide focuses on the configuration in EBRR and CBRR. Pricing configuration in Sales for SSP is covered in a separate blog, as it depends on the specific business process.

Prerequisites

  • Activate the relevant scope items for Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) and Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR).
  • For EBRR, there are separate scope items for each integration scenario, such as 1K2 (Event Based Revenue Recognition - Sell from Stock) or 3M4 Event-Based Revenue Recognition – Service Documents – IFRS (3M4)

Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) Setup

Start in the Profitability Analysis area under Revenue Recognition. This is the starting point because EBRR defines the integration scenarios.

Maintain Source for the condition (Optional)

If revenue contracts are used, each pricing condition type must be mapped to a source. The system checks this mapping during revenue contract creation. This step is optional if you do not change SAP’s default configuration, which already contains predefined mappings.

As you can see, SAP has predefined the mapping of the condition types to the sources.  If you introduce a new condition type or add a condition type to a pricing procedure, ensure you map it to a source in the EBRR configuration.

Example: if you add condition type DSV1 to the pricing scheme in Subscription Billing and DSV1 is not mapped, add DSV1 to source RPC and create custom rules (e.g., rule numbers starting from 1000).

This ensures the condition type is recognized during processing; otherwise, revenue contract creation will fail due to missing source mapping.

Maintain Accounts for the Posting (Optional)

Now we are in the second step, and this step is optional but usually every customer defines its own account.

 

The account determination during posting is defined in event-based revenue recognition. In most cases, you need to define the following accounts

  • Deferrals Account: you define the deferrals account of usage 100
  • Accrued/Contract Asset Account: you define the accruals account of usage 100
  • Revenue Account: Cost Element Accounts of usage 100
  • Unbilled Account: you define the accruals account of usage 103 and the cost element account shall be the same as the one in usage 100.

Maintain Billable Determination Method (required)

Per IFRS 15/ASC 606, you must define what is billable to distinguish billable amounts from contract assets. When 'Use Revenue Contracts' is set, the system validates that the revenue recognition key has a billable determination method.  In ‘Maintain settings’ for the Revenue Recognition Key, you define how billable is calculated.

Supported method:

  • Billable equals Invoice:
  • Billable follows Percentage of Completion: 
  • Billable at completion:

At least one billable determination method must be maintained for the key used in processing. Otherwise,  you may get an error at configuration to enable ‘Use Revenue Recontracts’ or later at period end run.

Use the new ‘Bundling Scenario’ Field to Enable ‘Use Revenue Contracts’

In this step, we define when a product of a process shall create revenue contract and how different products from different process shall be combined into single revenue contracts.

  • Open ‘Define Revenue Recognition Key’ for the relevant Process (e.g., Provider Contract for Subscription Billing).
  • Bundling Scenario is determined by whether an object is created standalone or from a Solution Order.
    • Per Standard Objects: When the object is created directly (without Solution Order).
    • Per Solution Order: When the object is created from a Solution Order

  • When Bundling Scenario is set to Per Solution Order, ‘Use Revenue Contract’ becomes active for the key.
  • With this, all objects created from a same Solution Order are combined into one revenue contract.
  • This behavior can be applied across different business processes (service contract, provider contract, project, sales order). For example, in one solution order there are service contracts and sales orders, and the revenue recognition key of the service contracts and sales orders are defined as ‘Use Revenue Contract’, the  one revenue contract will be created with POBs from each service contract and sales orders.

Advanced — Using revenue contracts for standalone objects

  • Using revenue contracts for standalone objects (when bundle scenario is per standalone Objects not created from Solution Order) is supported only via expert configuration.
  • Please raise a request to SAP; SAP reviews the business process and enables the setup if appropriate.

 

Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR) Setup

Maintain Contract Attributes using Business Rule Framework (BRF+) rules

Now we start the configuraiton in CBRR.

  • To enable revenue contract creation, maintain the BRF+ rules required by revenue contracts.
  • You  "Maintain Contract Attributes Business Rules"

Note: The system requires you at least trigger the configuration so that the businss rule is created and put into a transport request. 
You must also allow the pop-up option of your browser!!!

Since 2602, a well-defined pre-delivered configuration is available as part of the application, usually you would not need to change the pre-delivered rules from SAP.  The product ID is taken as the POB Name, and the fulill type and event type are preconfigured according to the reveneu recognition key.

 

Define Standalone Selling Price(Optional)

If the product cannot have a standalone selling price defined in the pricing procedure in solution order), you can still define the SSP using the rule ‘in CBRR. 

You can define the SSP per product and define how the SSP is calculated such as the amount is quarterly based, monthly

 

 

Up to now, the configuration is completed, and you can now run the End-2-End scenario starting from Solution Order to Financial Accounting.

entry.title: Re: Embedded TM (S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025): Cro...
entry.content:
Hello Ronald,

Yes, the Group Logistics Company Process is support only in Side Car TM, as mentioned in the Oss Note 3615236 - SAP S/4HANA 2025 Supply Chain for Transportation Management - Release information - SAP for Me

Having the Central Procurare company in TM you will need to follow the MM Organization Structure in TM so you can create your PO/SES/Invoice without problem for the Cross Integration.

By other hand you will need to enable the Cost distribution to have the ABD document and be able to have the cost of the transport in the material Valuation or CO-PA for the receiving Plant of this Transports.

As the  Group Logistics is not available in TM embedded you, I see as alternative use the value of the ABD document to have the internal cost recharge on FI side, to have the Intercompany cost process.

Regards,

Rogerio
